fields.headline: Squeeze on the BBC
fields.bodyText: Surely this is the beginning of the end for the BBC (Shock raid on BBC budget, 20 October)? That I'm sure is what this Tory-led government is hoping. Why freeze the budget for six years? Why not one year and then review it? Or is it that six years of being squeezed is the predicted time it will take before the BBC falls to its knees and can then be easily taken apart by this vicious pack of wolves. The BBC costs each of us just under 40p a day. That's 40p for a massive range of services – TV, local news, news online, radio and so much more – services that the commercial sector can only dream of. Michael Burgess Tunbridge Wells, Kent • The Murdoch payback begins ... Bob Nicholson Frodsham, Cheshire • It is extremely disappointing to find you devoting virtually the whole of a page to the unfortunate cat-in-the-bin lady (A modest fine, but no end to the outrage, 20 October). What she did was sad and cruel, but she has paid for it many times over. No doubt much sadder and crueller things were done in this country – unpublicised and unpunished – on the day in question. Christopher Scarles Eastbourne, East Sussex • What a relief to see a grown-up Wayne Rooney finally separating himself from this unbearable Uebervater Alex Ferguson (Comment, 20 October). Ferguson's attitude of disappointed boys-school headmaster, pumping guilt into his pupil's conscience, has taken quite an impact, but I still hope Rooney has the strength and courage to withstand Ferguson's hysterical performance. Norbert Andersch London • I recently attended the urology clinic at Musgrove Park hospital in Taunton (Letters, 20 October). The consultant was very efficient, but I was somewhat alarmed to learn that his name was Mr Burns-Cox. W Rosser Wellington, Somerset • I note that in your report "Half a sausage a day" (19 October) the spokesman for the meat producers is Mr Lamb. Joseph Cocker Leominster, Herefordshire
